node.title: How to Avoid
node.body:
Excuses and Penalties

  • Excuses Students Give for Academic Dishonesty
  • How You Can Avoid Situations that Lead to Academic Dishonesty
  • Penalties for Academic Dishonesty at Penn State

Excuses Students Give for Academic Dishonesty

Activity 4:

By now you should have read the materials on cheating, plagiarism, copyright, and fair use. Think about your past experiences as a student. Have you ever done anything academically dishonest? Intentionally? Unintentionally? Did you try to rationalize what you were doing with an excuse?

You may think you have a good excuse for academic dishonesty, but you should think again. (2)

I. "I'm too busy."

Maybe you think you have too many credits or are working too many hours to be able to complete your assignments. However, it is your responsibility to make sure you have scheduled adequate time to complete all your assignments.

If you discover that you do not have enough time to complete an assignment, it is far better to discuss your situation with your instructor or TA than to commit plagiarism.

The worst that can happen to you in this situation, is that you fail the class and have to retake it. While failing a class is embarrassing and retaking it is inconvenient, it is not as bad as being found guilty of academic dishonesty and receiving sanctions (see below).

II. "My work isn't good enough."

Maybe you feel that the quality of your work is so poor that you could never pass the class. Faculty do not expect your work to be 100% perfect. The purpose of any assignment is for you to learn and practice new skills.

If you feel your skills are especially weak, it is far better for you to discuss your concerns with your instructor. He or she may be able to point you to resources that can help you improve your grade.

Remember, it is always better to fail honestly than to be found guilty of academic dishonesty.

III. "Everyone else is doing it. I have to do it to just to keep up."

More than half of all Penn State students admit to cheating at some point in their college career. Students who don't cheat feel like they are put at an unfair disadvantage by students who do cheat. However, there is no evidence to show that students who cheat receive higher grades than those who don't cheat, nor is there any evidence to show they are hired for better jobs. In addition, the consequences of getting caught cheating far outweigh any momentary gains. It's better to fail a course and have to repeat it than to be found guilty of academic dishonesty and have a mark on your transcript for the rest of your life.

IV. "I need to cheat in order to have a high G.P.A."

Some students honestly feel that the only way to a high G.P.A. is through cheating, but that simply is not true. Students have achieved high G.P.A.'s without cheating, and, in fact, a Penn State Pulse survey and other studies have shown that students who cheat tend to have lower G.P.A.'s than students who do not cheat.

Ask yourself this: Would you want a doctor who passed his or her courses only because of cheating?

V. "I didn't know it was academic dishonesty."

It is your responsibility as a Penn State student to know what constitutes academic dishonesty. That's what this module is all about.

If you find that you are in a situation where you are not sure if your work could be construed as cheating, ask your instructor or look for examples of what not to do. Some sources of examples are provided earlier in this module and your department or college may have examples related specifically to that field.

VI. "They'll never find out."

Just because your instructors are busy faculty and TA's does not mean they are unaware. Many faculty are aware of online "paper mill" Web sites and have also seen enough other assignments to know if something looks "too familiar" or "doesn't seem right." In addition, educators are developing and using technologies which can look for similar phrases across papers. Penn State is now a member of "Turnitin.com," a resource that allows faculty to check papers against a vast database of information for occurrences of plagiarism.

VII. "I meant to include citations, but I forgot/ran out of time."

Get into the habit of inserting citations, even in your rough drafts. Using index cards for source information is one way you can keep track of your references, other methods are equally successful. If you don't know which citation to use, put some question marks in the draft and track it down later.

If you need to review citation guidelines, you can access the Penn State Library Citation Styles or explore the information and links in "How to Properly Cite a Source." There are many citation styles, so you should ask your instructor which one is appropriat for a particular class if he or she has not indicated a citation style for you to use.

How You Can Avoid Situations That Lead to Academic Dishonesty

Remember, upholding your personal academic integrity is your responsibility as a member of the university community, so plan ahead and make sure you understand your assignments and where you can go for help.

  1. Be proactive. If you don't understand an assignment or are unclear about your instructor's expectations, ask early in the semester. Don't wait until the last minute!
  2. Plan ahead. Look at the work load for all of your courses. When are your assignments due? How much work will each take? What can you start on right away? Will you need to learn a new citation style or method of research for any of these assignments?
  3. Know where to find information and resources.
    • citation styles
    • university polices on academic integrity
    • library resources
    • writing help - writing centers, on-line writing resources

Consequences for Academic Integrity Violations at Penn State

There is a University policy known as G-9 which provides direction for responding to academic integrity violations of the University's code of conduct. In addition, each college and campus have designed specific guidelines for responding to allegations and have the authority to impose sanctions on students who violate the academic integrity policy. Faculty members are responsible for conveying the allegation and sanction to the student, who can then choose to accept the charge and sanction or appeal to the College (or campus) academic integrity committee for a review or hearing. The outcome of that review or hearing is final and cannot be appealed. When disciplinary sanctions are recommended, the case will be managed by the Office of Judicial Affairs (www.sa.psu.edu/ja/) or a Judicial Affairs designee. 

The outcome of all academic integrity cases is sent to the Office of Judicial Affairs or the Judicial Affairs designee for record-keeping.  When a student is found responsible for a violation, the student's previous academic integrity history will be viewed and a more serious sanction could be assigned as a result of repeated misconduct.

In Fall 2000, Penn State instituted the XF grade, which is a disciplinary sanction assigned to students found responsible for committing extreme acts of academic dishonesty. The XF grade will appear on the student's official transcript and states that the student's grade was assigned specifically because he or she committed an act of academic dishonesty. For the 2001-2002 school year, 268 cases of academic dishonesty were reported, resulting in various penalties including five XF grades and several dismissals from academic programs.

In addition to the XF grade, there are a number of other sanctions that could be imposed when a student is found responsible for academic dishonesty, including warnings, letter grade reductions, and/or disciplinary sanctions such as probation or expulsion.

Many colleges and campuses at Penn State have their own policy statements on academic integrity which are based on the University-wide policy, 49-20. Here are links to some of them (2).

Penn State System

  • Senate Policy 49-20 "Academic Integrity "

College Policy Statements

  • College of Earth and Mineral Sciences Integrity Policy
  • College of Education Integrity Policy
  • College of Engineering Integrity Policy
  • College of Liberal Arts Integrity Policy
  • Eberly College of Science Integrity Policy
  • School of Information Sciences and Technology Integrity Policy
  • World Campus Integrity Policy

Campus Policy Statements

  • Altoona Integrity Policy
  • Erie, The Behrend College Integrity Policy
  • Greater Allegheny Integrity Policy

node.title: Code of Mutual Respect and Cooperation
node.body:
The Eberly College of Science Code of Mutual Respect and Cooperation pertains to all members of the college community; faculty, staff, and students.

The Code of Mutual Respect and Cooperation was developed to embody the values that we hope our faculty, staff, and students possess, consistent with the aspirational goals expressed in the Penn State Principles. The University is strongly committed to freedom of expression, and consequently, the Code does not constitute University or College policy, and is not intended to interfere in any way with an individual’s academic or personal freedoms. We hope, however, that individuals will voluntarily endorse the 12 principles set forth in the Code, thereby helping us make the Eberly College of Science a place where every individual feels respected and valued, as well as challenged and rewarded.

The 12 Principles of the Code are:
  1. Treat everyone equally and with respect
  2. Be courteous
  3. Be ready to communicate
  4. Encourage others and share your expertise with them
  5. Give and accept constructive criticism
  6. Be receptive to change
  7. Be a team player
  8. Get involved
  9. Have a positive attitude
  10. Be honest and accept responsibility
  11. Recognize other people’s priorities
  12. Strive to do your best

A member of ANGEL support will be in contact with you to assist you.

node.title: Principles of Scientific Writing
node.body:
Use these guidelines whenever you are preparing a scientific document. Conciseness is just as important as completeness and accuracy.

  1. Avoid the use of pronouns: I, you, he, she, they, them, our, your, it, and so forth.
  2. Write in complete sentences.
  3. Paginate your work, even if it consists of a single page.
  4. Be sure to put your name in the page header or footer, starting with page 2.
  5. Express temperature in degrees Celsius rather than degrees Fahrenheit.  For example, the normal temperature of the human body is 37°, not 98.6°.
  6. Be certain to cite the source of any data or idea that is not your own.
  7. Do not repeat the same idea. Write it once, and then move onto the next thought.
  8. Be concise and to the point. Scientific writing is not an exercise in creative writing. Also, be sure your work is free of “science fiction.”
  9. Be sure to check your written work for typographical and grammatical errors before handing it in. Nothing detracts from the quality of written work like errors in spelling, punctuation, and sentence structure.
  10. Consider having someone proofread your paper before submitting it. Often, another set of eyes can detect problems that may have been missed due to fatigue.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
We live in a technology-driven world and it would be hard to imagine a world without cell phones, i‐pods, antibiotics, a criminal justice system, and food on our tables, just to name a few. You only need to open a newspaper, or turn on the TV and you will be inundated with topics such as:

  • Climate change
  • Species extinction
  • Nutrition and health
  • Pandemics
  • Cloning
  • Stem cells

Yet a recent Pew and AAAS survey report that only 52% of Americans know the difference between stem cells and normal cells, and despite 84% of scientists believing that human emissions are causing global warming, only 49% of the general American public think the same.

Many of us don't value science as much as we should. However, science lives beneath the surface of everything we touch and taste. It is the key to our prosperity, one of the driving forces of our economy, and it creates hundreds of thousands of jobs.

Despite the fact that science is, and will continue to be, part of our daily lives, statistics from Michigan State University report that in 2007 only 28% of American adults qualify as scientifically literate.

Module 1 Topics and Checklist

Module 1 will cover the following topics:

  • Examples of science in contemporary life
  • Explanation of what this laboratory portion of the course will cover
  • How to use Google Docs and VoiceThread for this course
  • Explanation of how the course will work

node.title: Lesson 02: Why is Science Important?
node.body:
Curiosity and casual observation can only get you so far in today's fast-paced world where there are a number of issues that require some understanding of science.

Watch this short video to learn why science is so important today.

Video: Importance of Science

Click on the video below to begin.

Open the transcript of this video if you would like to read or print the information.

Contrary to popular belief, science is not a list of facts to be remembered, but rather it is an intellectual activity that encompasses observation, description, experimentation, and explanation of phenomena. In other words, science is a pathway to discover and better understand the world around us.

node.title: Lesson 04: What are we Going to Do in this Part of the Course?
node.body:
Scientific thinking is an important element in the study of a wide range of topics--from economics, through health, to the environment. We will focus on biology (or the study of living things), and using real‐world examples we will develop a new level of biological literacy.
 
Biological literacy is the ability to:
 
  • Use the method of scientific inquiry to think creatively about real‐world biological (e.g. health and environment) issues.
  • Integrate these ideas into decision-making processes.
Biological issues such as obesity, stem cell research, genetically modified crops, swine flu, fossil fuel use, and global warming appear frequently in the news, and as such, they have become politically charged subjects. An enhanced biological literacy level should help you to make wiser, more informed decisions for yourself, and ultimately, for society at large.
 
Science is an integral part of technology, and where this course probably differs from other courses, is that we are using and integrating new web-based technologies to enhance the learning environment. In doing so, this course is:
 
  • Contemporary - integrates real-world issues into the course content.
  • Flexible - it is online so you can manage your own time and decide when and where you want to learn.
  • Multidisciplinary - while we are focusing on biology, many of the skills learned will be directly transferable to other disciplines (science or non-science).

In addition, you will be developing digital literacy skills that will be beneficial in your future post-university years.

node.title: Lesson 06: Using VoiceThread
node.body:
A VoiceThread is a collaborative, multimedia slide show that holds images, documents, and videos. It allows you to navigate pages and, most importantly, leave comments on any of the media within it. You have already viewed a VoiceThread in Lesson 3, and you will be seeing many more as small instructional pieces throughout the modules. Later on in the course you will get to create your own media and post comments on a VoiceThread of your own. In the meantime, we have a required assessment in this module where you will practice using VoiceThread.

The steps below will help you get started with VoiceThread so that you can complete the required assessment for Module 1.

Step 1: Become familiar with VoiceThread

Before you get started with VoiceThread, visit the VoiceThread at Penn State website. There are various resources to help get you started, including frequently asked questions as well as a VoiceThread forum for tips.

Step 2: Watch a VoiceThread and Leave a Comment

Your first exercise in working with VoiceThread will be to leave a comment on one. To do this:

  1. Follow this "VoiceThread Link" to get everything set up for this course.
  2. After signing in, you should see a message that you have become a member of the group "Biology110_Summer2012_Section001" (your section number).
  3. Next, click the My Voice tab.
  4. Find the VoiceThread titled "Bio110 Mod 1 Assignment -Section###" and click on it.
  5. Click on the Comment button and then choose your method of leaving a comment.

Listen to the instructor's comment and then comment with your name, major and any other information you would like to share.

Step 3: Learn How to Create Your own VoiceThread

Along with being able to make a comment on someone else's VoiceThread, you will also need to be able to create your own VoiceThread presentation. As part of the assessment for Module 01, you will be asked to:

  • Create your own VoiceThread,
  • Upload an image,
  • Make a comment and
  • Share your VoiceThread with your TA

Please click here for the Module 01 Assessment Part 2: VoiceThread Google Doc instructions and then submit to Module 01 Assessments Part 1 and 2 - Drop Box by Friday, July 15th at 11:00PM Eastern Time.

node.title: Lesson 07: Course Structure and Features
node.body:
Learning the process of science cannot be done overnight. Rather, just like a plumber or a carpenter has a toolbox full of the tools needed for their trade to get the job done, we will methodically gather the scientific tools needed to place in our scientific toolbox so that we can better understand the process of science, assess science in the media, and make informed conclusions and decisions based on the information presented.

The course runs over the session and has the following structure--all of which is accessible through ANGEL:
 
  • Module 01: Introduction
  • Module 02: The Scientific Method
  • Module 03: Descriptive Statistics
  • Module 04: Graphs
  • Module 05: Inferential Statistics
  • Module 06: Integration
  • Module 07: Science and Media
  • Module 08: Climate Change
  • Module 09: Pandemics
  • Module 10: Final Assessment- Group Project
Help
As you have read so far, this course will have you working with new learning technologies and you may need some help with them on occasion. You can access the course help page while in any module by selecting the Help tab.
 
Give us your Feedback Anytime
You are encouraged to voice your opinions and feedback so that this course can continue to evolve. You are just as integral to this course as the faculty is - so lets have fun and learn together!
 
To provide your feedback at any time during this course, access the Course Feedback tab and use the short form to submit your comment.
 
Module 1 Wrap-up 

You have just finished Module 1. If you have any questions, please email your TA via ANGEL. Alternatively, if there is anything in this module that you would like to comment on, or add to, please visit the "Course Feedback" link in the top menu.

You can now return to ANGEL to complete the Lesson 1 Assessment, Parts 1 and 2 and the syllabus assessment. These assessments are located in the Module 1 folder.

You have just finished Module 2. If you have any questions, please email the instructor via ANGEL.  You can now return to ANGEL to complete the Module 02 Assessment.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
If you have ever watched Animal Planet or Discovery Channel, you will be familiar with Sir David Attenborough. He is probably the best-known natural history filmmaker, whose career as a naturalist and broadcaster has spanned nearly five decades. There are very few places on this Earth that he has not visited.

We have had a brief look at why science is important, but this is what Sir David Attenborough had to say when asked about the importance of science.

The good news is that you do not need a science degree to be able to understand science. We as humans have a big brain that enables us to explain how things work by using methodical, objective, and rational observation and analysis--thereby setting us apart from other species such as those that appear in Sir David Attenborough's movies.  However, curiosity and casual observation can only get us so far in today's fast paced world where there are a number of issues that require some understanding of science.

Lab Module 2 will cover a description of the scientific method.

node.title: Lesson 02: Questioning the Facts
node.body:
"How do I know that it is true?"

This is a question that you have no doubt asked yourself a hundred times before. It is also a very important question in today's world. Lets start by looking at a common example that we are faced with in everyday life.

Read: Article about Marketing False Claim

Read this article about how a marketing firm was sued for false scientific claims, "FTC: CortiSlim, CortiStress marketers made false claims"

This is not an isolated case, and one of the benefits of having knowledge of science is that it can help us from being fooled by false claims that links exist between two things, when in fact they do not. This is very important in our fast-paced information-overloaded world because the media frequently cite:

Thus, contrary to popular belief, science is not just a list of facts to be remembered but rather it is an intellectual activity that encompasses observation, description, experimentation, and explanation of phenomena. In other words, science is a pathway to discover and better understand the world around us, and hence aid in our decision-making.

  • Pseudoscience - where people make scientific‐sounding claims that are not supported by valid scientific studies - e.g. 4 out of 5 doctors recommend drug X to cure backache. Did they ask 5 doctors and if so, is this really representative of all doctors as a whole? Or did they interview a large sample number of doctors representing a good range of the population. These statements are often used to try and sell products.
  • Anecdotal observations ‐ where people conclude that there is a link between things based on a single or very few observations - e.g. you hear of a cancer patient that beat the odds by drinking prune juice. It may seem harmless but they don't include large or representative observations, and can therefore lead people to make incorrect conclusions.

node.title: Lesson 03: The Scientific Method
node.body:
An understanding of the scientific method is a good start because learning about science (and its role in society) without learning the process of science is like trying to learn a foreign language with a dictionary as opposed to taking classes.

Video: Scientific Method

The scientific method is not a scary technical term, but rather, it is a process of discovery that provides a useful approach to understanding the world. Right click on the video below and select 'Play" to learn more about the scientific method.

The four basic steps in the scientific method therefore are:
  1. Make an observation
  2. Formulate a hypothesis
  3. Conduct a critical experiment
  4. Draw conclusions and make revisions

The steps in the method will first be introduced in their generic form and then then reinforced through a worked example.

1. Make an observation

A scientific study always begins with an observation. In effect, you are looking for interesting patterns or cause‐and-effect relationships. In effect, you will generate an interesting question, or set of questions, which will serve as the starting point of your discovery.

2. Formulate hypothesis

You have no doubt all come up with a 'theory' about something from time to time. For example you may have a 'theory that the traffic to university is less if you wake up late.' Unfortunately, the word 'theory' is often used to refer to a guess or speculation, whereas in science, a theory is the complete opposite - i.e. something of undeniable certainty - e.g. all organisms are composed of cells. So when you use the word 'theory,' what you are in effect really meaning is a hypothesis.

Based on observations, the next step is to develop a hypothesis, or a proposed explanation for observed phenomena. The important thing about a hypothesis is that it needs to be:

  • Testable - the validity of a hypothesis can only be evaluated by putting it to the test.
  • Falsifiable - a hypothesis must be stated in such a way that you can imagine an observation that would prove it untrue (false).
  • It is also important to realize that it is impossible to prove that a hypothesis is absolutely true, as future evidence, when it becomes available, may show that it is not true. As such, hypotheses are generally posed as a negative statement where there is no relationship between two factors.

A hypothesis that states no relationship is termed a Null hypothesis, which can be disproved by any observation that contradicts it.

While the use of a null hypothesis does seem to make some sense, it does raise the problem of what if you do find an effect. This is a valid question that can easily be overcome by stating an Alternative hypothesis, where the converse of the null is stated, and therefore gives you something to accept if you reject the Null hypothesis. It is important to remember that the Alternative hypothesis never makes any predictive statements--it merely states that there is an effect, but not what that effect is.

So in summary,
  • Null hypothesis: states that there is no effect.
  • Alternative hypothesis: states that there is an effect, but not what the effect is.

3. Conduct a critical experiment

One of the most effective ways to test a hypothesis is through some form of experimentation. The information that is collected from the experiments is called data. It is this data that is used to actually test the hypothesis (i.e. do I reject or accept my hypothesis?).

Experiments in their most basic form help you determine the cause‐and‐effect relationship between two things. The information that is collected during the experimental (data gathering) process provides the information that you use to formulate a conclusion. In your daily lives, you may not actually be conducting critical experiments, but accessing and sorting through information from multiple sources to generate a conclusion is akin to the experimental process of a scientist.

4. Draw conclusions and make revisions

Once you have the results from the experiment (or information you have gathered from sources), you need to examine and analyze them. This entails looking for patterns and relationships from the data gathered in the experiments. From these, conclusions are drawn to see whether the findings support the hypothesis.

Science is a fluid process that involves a lot of trial and error over time, so if your conclusions do not support your hypothesis, then you can revise your hypothesis, and start the experimental process again - i.e. revise and start again.  This is the cornerstone of scientific discovery because it requires an open mind and the ability to change what you think.

node.body:
Module 3 Topics and Checklist

  • Standard deviation

Complete all the activities in this lab module and take the Module 03 Assessment by June 22nd at 11:00 PM Eastern Time.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
You are becoming familiar with the scientific process, and in particular, hypothesis generation and testing. You have also looked at basic examples of hypothesis testing and experimental design.

However, the world is a little more complex than what has been talked about so far, and many different studies are conducted that may be of interest to you.  So let's continue our discovery by looking more closely at data.

  • How is it gathered?
  • How is it treated once gathered?
  • How is it used to test hypotheses? 

Learning the process of science cannot be done overnight. Rather, just like a plumber or a carpenter has a toolbox full of the tools needed for their trade to get the job done.  Now that you are familiar with the scientific method, over the next few weeks you will start to compile your scientific toolbox that will arm you with all the tools you need to critically test hypotheses. The first step is to understand the differences between a population and a sample, as well as calculating averages and measures of variability.

node.title: Lesson 02: Samples and Populations
node.body:
Congratulations! This definitely sounds like a great achievement. We are Penn State!

While this may (or may not) make you proud, let's take a closer look at this study. Did you get asked questions as part of this survey?  Did your friends?  Did your dorm neighbor?

I am guessing that your answer to most of these questions is NO.

There are an estimated 14 million students in U.S. universities, and, while the survey sample size of 122,000 university students may seem like a lot, does this result represent the populous view of U.S. university students?

How practical/easy do you think it would be to question all 14 million U.S. university students? It would be a difficult task. So how do you test hypotheses if you cannot use the entire population?

This has already been alluded to in your simple experimental design where you used a subset of people to test your hypotheses about fast food and obesity—i.e. you sub-sampled. In effect, you are making inferences about the entire population based on the smaller sample.

Definitions

Population: The group of individuals, or items, to be studied is called the population (N).

E.g. The U.S. university student population in the "Party School" example.

E.g. The adult U.S. population in the "Fast Food and Obesity" example.

Sample: A subset (n) of the entire population (N).  Those people, objects, or events selected from the population for inclusion in the study.

E.g. The 122,000 students surveyed in the "Party School" example.

E.g. The 50 control group and 50 treatment group individuals in the "Fast Food and Obesity" example.

Note that the notation for the entire population is an uppercase N, whereas for the sample it is a lowercase n.

 

Here are a few more examples of different situations to help illustrate the difference between samples and populations.

node.title: Lesson 03: Normal Distribution
node.body:
Will sub-sampling not provide a biased estimate of the population?

To answer this you need to step back and look at populations in nature. In nature, most populations have what is called a normal distribution. Put simply, it turns out that middle values tend to occur more frequently, with outliers, or extreme values, occurring less frequently. This is why you don't see basketball player-sized people as frequently as you see average height individuals. Let's illustrate what we mean by looking at the distribution of IQ scores in a population.

Video: Distribution of IQ Scores in a Population

To play the video, right click and select play.  To pause the video, right click and uncheck the play option.

Open the transcript of this distribution video if you would like to read or print the information.

So, in theory, if you take enough individuals in your sample, you should get more of the middle values, and therefore, a result that resembles that of the population. The million-dollar question, however, is how many is enough for the sample to be representative of the population?

Now that you are more familiar with the difference between a sample and a population, you can start to address this question.

Returning to the 'Party School' example. If there are an estimated 14 million students in US universities, 122,000 represents just less than 1% of the US university population. Moreover, on average, there were 325 respondents to the survey per school, which in Penn State's case amounts to less than 1% of the University Park campus' enrollment of 43,000 students.

Based on this information, would you consider the sample size to be sufficient to draw a definitive conclusion?

While you may like to say yes (due to the pride of going to the top party school), I am sure you will agree that a sample of less than 1% of the population may not be adequate in this case.

So if you are going to enjoy wearing this new party badge, keep in mind the actual validity behind the results.

It is therefore important to keep in mind that the primary point of sampling is to create a small group from a population that is as similar to the larger population as possible. In essence, you want to have a little group that is like the big group. With that in mind, one of the features you look for in a sample is the degree of representativeness--how well does the sample represent the larger population from which it was drawn?

node.title: Lesson 04: Types of Data
node.body:
Now that you have a better idea of how data is gathered, lets look at how is it treated once gathered.

First, let's introduce the common different types of data that you may have, or will come across.

  • Binary data - generally Yes/No.
  • Categorical data - where individuals are placed into categories e.g. male and female.
  • Continuous data - most commonly used where finer measurements are taken e.g. weight, blood pressure, speed etc.

Binary and categorical data are commonly used in social science and behavioral science, whereas continuous data is commonly used in the life sciences.

Examples:

  • Binary - questionnaire - have you ever suffered from a heart condition? (Yes/No); did you graduate from high school? (Yes/No).
  • Categorical - smoking status (none, light, heavy); hair color (blond, brown, black, red).
  • Continuous - weight gain, size of fish, death rates, carbon emissions per country.

Self Check: Different Types of Data

Try this Self-Check to see whether you can differentiate the types of data.

node.title: Lesson 05: Averages
node.body:
Once an experiment (or survey) is conducted, the results are recorded in their raw form - e.g. each measure per individual is recorded. The end result usually would be a spreadsheet, which consists of a lot of numbers. However, this raw data does not tell you anything about the effect you may be trying to test, and therefore cannot be used to test your hypotheses in the raw form.

VoiceThread: Averages

Let's illustrate this using an example that you are no doubt very familiar with--exams and anxiety (stress).

Open the transcript of the Averages VoiceThread if you would like to read or print the information.

Self-Check: Averages

Test your ability to calculate the Mean using this self-check quiz.

Sample Size and Sample Mean

Sample means are sensitive to extreme values, so a single data point can make a noticeable change in the sample mean--especially if the sample size is small. Remember that the primary point of sampling is to create a small group from a population that is as similar to the larger population as possible. Ultimately, you want the sample Mean (X) to approximate the population Mean (m).

Interactive Exercise: Impact of Sample Size on Sample Mean

Try this exercise where you can enter different sample sizes to see how the sample mean differs from the population mean depending on sample size.

Open the animation transcript if you would like to read or print the information.

You should notice that the calculated sample means get closer to the actual population mean as the sample size increases. Based on the normal probability, the more samples that are taken will increase the number of values that are closer to the population mean and the effect of the outlier values will be reduced accordingly.

node.title: Lesson 06: Variability
node.body:
As a sample is very unlikely to reflect the population exactly in all respects, there will always be some uncertainty as to how well the sample results reflect the population. You don't know the population mean, yet you would like to know it, which is why you need to draw your conclusion from the sample mean.

But besides calculating the sample mean, there is a need to access the precision (or spread) of the data to determine whether the calculated sample mean is an accurate estimate of the population mean.

Other simple statistical measures can be used to reduce or quantify the uncertainty, i.e. to measure the variability.

VoiceThread: Standard Deviation

The Standard Deviation is the most common measure of variability, measuring the spread of the data set and the relationship of the mean to the rest of the data--i.e. the precision of the data.

Open the transcript for the Standard Deviation VoiceThread if you would like to read or print the information.

Self-Check: Standard Deviation

Test your ability to calculate the Standard Deviation using this self-check quiz.

Do you remember the million-dollar question of how many is enough for the sample to be representative of the population? The Standard Deviation can greatly help answer this question.

Interactive Exercise: Sample Size and Standard Deviation

Try this exercise where you can enter different sample sizes to see how the standard deviation changes depending on sample size.

Open the animation transcript if you would like to read or print the information.

You will notice that as the sample size increases, the standard deviation generally decreases. This is because the more samples that you take, you are getting a better representation of the scatter in the data (i.e. increasing the number of samples that fit closer to the population mean, and eliminating the weight given to outlier values).

So, whenever possible, the more samples that can be taken the better. The bigger the sample size, the better the sample mean will approximate the population mean. While this is the ideal, logistical constraints in terms of time, manpower, cost, and ethics often factor in to the sample size used.

Module 3 Wrap-up

Congratulations, you have just gathered your first tools to put into the toolbox and you should now have a better understanding of the difference between samples and populations, as well as the ability to calculate the Mean and Standard Deviation. As such, you are well on your way to enhanced scientific understanding and discovery.

If you have any questions, please email the instructor via ANGEL. Furthermore, feel free to visit the "Course Feedback" link in the top menu if there is anything about this module that you would like to comment on or bring to our attention.  All comments and suggestions will greatly improve the module for future classes.

You can now return to ANGEL to complete the Lesson 3 Assessment.

node.title: Lesson 02: Graphs
node.body:
Now that you have a better understanding of the calculation and use of means and standard deviations, lets explore a little about how they are used not only in science, but in popular media and advertising.

Because we live in a visual world, graphs are often used in newspapers, magazines, and sports statistics because they communicate information visually.

Scientists frequently use graphs to compare effects of variables, look at trends as they develop, and examine hypotheses. In a way, figures are a language through which scientists communicate. While the ability to interpret graphs and tables is a necessary skill in science, it also finds use in everyday life. In articles or textbooks you are likely to find graphs, yet understanding the message will often depend on being able to interpret the many different types of graphs that are presented (such as those appearing in this weeks Biol Daily Times in Lesson 03).

Graphs should be there to aid you, not scare you, so lets take an introductory look into the interpretation of data presented on graphs.

While graphs are used in all forms of media, there are a few fundamentals that you should be aware of when assessing a graph. Graphs should be 'stand alone' items - i.e. they should not need any further explanation to make sense of them. Besides pie charts that have no axes, a reputable graph should have the following:

  1. Graphs have a X- (horizontal) and a Y- (vertical) axis. Both the X- and the Y-axes need a label (name). This is important because the person reading the graph needs to know what they are looking at. If it just says 1, 2, 3--what do these numbers represent? It could be cats, drugs, money, fish, etc. A graph without labeled axes is meaningless.
  2. The X-axis usually holds the independent variable (normally the variable that you have control over), and the Y-axis usually holds the dependent variable (the value depends on the value of the independent variable).
  3. If the numbers used on either the X- or Y-axes contain some measurement unit (e.g. miles, pounds, dollar value, etc.), the unit measurements must accompany the axes label. Once again, the reader needs this information to be able to make sense of what they are looking at.
  4. Graphs need a title (figure legend). The figure legend provides a short explanation of what the graph represents. The figure legend ALWAYS should appear BELOW the graph. Figure legends should NEVER be placed ABOVE the graph.

node.title: Lesson 03: Types of Graphs
node.body:
When looking at a graph, it is always good to get an idea about the context: Why was this graph created, i.e. what is the bigger picture behind this graph?

node.title: Lesson 04: Graphing Scales
node.body:
One final consideration when interpreting a graph(s) is to make sure that the scales of the axes are appropriate--especially when comparing multiple data sets. This is a form of trickery that is often used in the media and in advertising, where the scales are changed to enhance or reduce an effect.

Take the North Atlantic storm data once again and see what happens when the axis changes.

It becomes immediately apparent that the trend looks far less dramatic when a scale of 0-100 is used as opposed to 7-15. If the Y-axis units were conveniently omitted (which happens a lot when people are trying to push a point of view), you would never know that the graph on the left was hiding the true data trend.

In much the same way, when graphs are used as a visual display of hypothesis testing, a plot of the raw data is going to be equally as meaningless as the raw data table.

However, you are now experts at summarizing the raw data by calculating Means to get an 'average' and Standard Deviations to assess the 'variability.' If you have more than a single measurement for a variable, then the Means and Standard Deviations are also the most effective metrics to use when plotting your results.

node.title: Lab Module 5: Inferential Statistics
node.body:
Module 5 will cover the following topics:

  • T-tests

Complete all the activities in this lab module and submit Module 05 Assessment by July 3rd at 11:00 PM Eastern Time to the Module 05 Assessment drop box.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
Up until now, you have been using descriptive statistics and simple graphical representations. In effect you have been taking a set of data and finding the best way to describe, summarize, and display it--considering both individual variables, and relationships among variables.

However, while this information can be used to draw some initial conclusions, it does not allow you to make a definitive test of your hypotheses--which is the cornerstone of scientific discovery.

While descriptive statistics and graphs are great to summarize the data and get a sense for what it is showing, in most cases, inferential statistics are used to actually test the hypothesis. In effect, inferential statistics are the science of extrapolating the results of a study to make claims about the larger population, i.e. procedures that allow us to decide whether our sample is representative of the population or not, and as such, allows us to make accurate inferences about the population represented in our samples (e.g. the US university student population in the 'Party School' example and the adult US population in the 'Fast Food and Obesity' example).

Inferential statistics are used to make generalizations from a sample to a population. In any study where the entire population is not sampled, there are two sources of error that may result in a sample mean being different from (not representative of) the population mean from which it is drawn:

Sample bias:

  • There is the possibility that some of the experimental subjects may consciously or unconsciously model their behavior based on what they think the researcher expects from them.
  • The researcher may make consistent errors in the measurements and evaluation of the results.

This bias is the result of a poorly designed experiment and can be easily overcome by designing what is called a blind experiment where the subjects and researcher/measurement taker are not aware of who is in the experimental or in the control group. It is important to have a sound experimental design before the data is generated because once the experiment begins there is no way to reverse the design without staring over again.

Sampling error

  • Introduced by chance - i.e. a random error.

Inferential statistics do not take into account sample bias as it is a research design issue. Rather, inferential statistics only take into account sampling error, i.e. address random error (chance). This is why it is important to have a good experimental design if you want to have confidence in your hypothesis testing.

node.title: Lesson 02: Probability
node.body:
Remember that the first step of hypothesis testing is to convert the research question into null and alternative hypotheses. The null hypothesis is a claim of "no difference," whereas the alternative hypothesis is a claim of "a difference in the population."

One of the surprising things about science is that it's actually almost impossible to prove anything true. Instead, all you do is show that things are false. So instead of proving your hypothesis, you just try to prove that all of the alternatives are wrong.

To do this, you need to use inferential statistics to calculate a test statistic from the data. The test statistic is then converted to a conditional probability called a p-value (p = probability).

VoiceThread: Probability

Open the transcript of this VoiceThread if you would like to read or print the information.

While 95% is generally acceptable in biological research, medical research generally uses a 99% (or 0.01) probability value, where the risk of getting a result by chance is only 1 out of 100. It is not too difficult to see why this is the case when you are dealing with potential fatal disease diagnoses and treatments etc.

node.title: Lesson 03: T-tests
node.body:
If you cast your minds back, you will remember that there are three types of data that have been spoken about--binary, categorical, and continuous. There are different inferential statistical tests for each of the data types.

Statistical tests do not have to be difficult. All of the tests you will do follow simple mathematical equations that you should be comfortable with. For continuous data, they simply use the information that goes into the Mean and the Standard Deviation, of which you are now experts.

t-test (continuous data)

Most biological data is continuous data, and a t-test is the simplest and most common statistical procedure used for comparing or contrasting Means from only two groups (think "t for two").

Up until now you have been working with a few different studies that would be appropriate for a t-test:

  • The 'Fast Food and Obesity' study
  • The 'Exams and Anxiety' study

While both of these studies are comparing two means, there is a fundamental difference in these two studies.

  • The 'Fast Food and Obesity' study has two independent groups--a treatment group and a control group. The individuals in each of these two groups are not the same.
  • The 'Exams and Anxiety' study on the other hand uses measurements from the same individuals--a normal and exam day measurement. The individuals in each of the two groups are the same, and therefore, the results are dependent on each other.

Given these differences, there are two types of t-tests depending on the type of study.

  • Independent (unpaired) t-test
  • Dependent (paired) t-test

While the underlying mechanics are the same, they use different formulas.

Let's use these studies as worked examples to show how to perform a t-test, and hence see how p-values are calculated and used in hypothesis testing.

VoiceThread: Unpaired (independent) t-test

Open the transcript for this VoiceThread if you would like to read or print the information.

VoiceThread: Paired (dependent) t-test

node.body:
Let's consolidate the past few lessons and return to something that you have no doubt covered before while at school, and look at 'plant sex' and pollination.

Open the transcript of the plant structures video if you would like to read or print the information.

Interactive Exercise: Key Reproductive Structures of a Flower

To test your knowledge of the key reproductive structures of a flower, try this exercise.

Open the transcript of the pollination video if you would like to read or print this information.

Video: Reproduction

The final piece in the puzzle occurs after pollination, i.e. fertilization. If fertilization is successful, the end result will be the development into fruit and the eventual dispersal of genetic information contained in the seeds.

Open the transcript of the reproduction video if you would like to read or print this information.

node.title: Lesson 03: Thinking about Impact
node.body:
Plants and pollinators have co-evolved physical characteristics that make them more likely to interact successfully, which has, in turn, led to the great diversity of flowers in nature. The plants benefit from attracting a particular type of pollinator to its flower, ensuring that its pollen will be carried to another flower of the same species and hopefully resulting in successful reproduction.

Plants and pollinators do not have the same goals. Plants want to maximize the spread of pollen to new individuals, while at the same time minimize the energetic costs of producing pollen and nectar to attract pollinator vectors. Pollinators, on the other hand, want to maximize energetic rewards of high quality food in the form of proteinaceous pollen and sugary nectar, while at the same time minimize the cost of foraging. These seemingly antagonistic goals can result in highly specialized relationships between plant and pollinator symbionts.

Some of the pollinators that you may have learned about include:

While this may seem familiar to you now, it probably brings up the age-old question from most of your school science classes: Why do I care?

Video: Why care about Bees?

Who cares about bees? Their stings are painful and less bees would be a good thing. Or would it? Watch this video to learn more:

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
Hopefully by now the age old myth that science is boring and not relevant to your life is slowly disappearing, as science affects you from the time you wake up until the time you finally go to sleep. Your alarm clock, the weather report, the asphalt you drive on, the bus or car that you ride in, your cell phone, your mp3 player, the tablets that treat your headache (yes you know why), the clean water that comes from your faucet, and the light that you turn off at the end of the day have all been brought to you courtesy of science. While scientific knowledge improves your quality of life, an understanding of science is imperative in the modern world in guiding your decisions on issues such as energy, conservation, agriculture, health, transportation, communication, defense, and economics.

If you are not planning on becoming an active academic scientist, you probably will never get to set-up and do your own experiment, but it is useful to have a good understanding of the scientific method. While much of the scientific information that you will read will probably come from the popular media and/or books, most of this research will first have been published in scientific journals (primary literature). Hundreds of scientific articles are published each week covering disciplines from health to environmental sciences.

Unless you plan on becoming an active scientist, it is unlikely that you will ever read the primary scientific literature. However, much of the scientific information that you will read will probably come from the popular media, which often reports on research that was first published in the primary scientific literature. So lets just take a quick look at the scientific publication process.

VoiceThread: The scientific publication process

Open the transcript of this VoiceThread if you would like to read or print the information.

node.title: Lesson 02: Science, the Media, and You
node.body:
Unless you plan on becoming an active scientist, it is unlikely that you will ever troll through and read the primary scientific literature every week. Instead, you will probably get your scientific information from secondary sources like the popular media. Even in these secondary sources you are constantly confronted with claims about household products, technology, medicine, and even politics--often steeped in the presumed authority of scientific research. These media representations of science and science-related policy are essential for quickly communicating scientific messages to the broad public, however, some important parts of the scientific message can easily get lost or garbled in translation. As such, 76% of US scientists believe that the news media does a poor job at educating the public and believe that a major problem for science is that news reports fail to distinguish between findings that are well-founded and those that are not.

How can you as a non-scientist decide what to believe?

An original piece of scientific research is often adapted into a simplified press release, which is picked up by reporters and translated again into a newspaper, magazine, or Internet article. Needless to say, details can very easily be lost in this chain. However, an understanding of the scientific method and the nature of science are useful skills to make you a better-informed consumer of these media messages and policies, and therefore separate science fact from science fiction.

node.title: Lesson 03: Science in the Media Checklist
node.body:
You now have a better understanding of the scientific method and how science works, so you should be in a better position to evaluate the constant information thrown at you via the Internet, television, radio, newspaper, magazine, or advertisement. Using your new-found knowledge in combination with this "science in the media checklist" should increase your scientific literacy significantly.

Using this simple checklist should help in separating the fact from the fiction. However, you may not be able to get answers to all the boxes, but the more marks in the green boxes should indicate a more trustworthy source than a list riddled with red box marks. Lets expand on this checklist and take a closer look behind the boxes.

Interactive Exercise: Science in Media Checklist

Try this interactive exercise to learn more details about each of the six elements of the science in media checklist.

Open the transcript for this video if you would like to read or print the information.

Not all the necessary information will always be presented to tick all the boxes in the list. Clearly, the more boxes you can tick, the better your appraisal of the media report will be. A good source should provide much of the information needed to address all boxes, but if you are unsure or require additional information, you can always contact the scientist(s) directly or go back to the original scientific journal article, which not only contains the original information, but is free of media bias.

If you do not have the checklist, remember these few key questions to guide you:

  • What's the claim?
  • Who is making the claim?
  • What's the evidence?
  • Does the data support the claim?
  • Could there be another explanation?

Finally, keep in mind the hype factor. Big news sells, and science stories are easy prey for people looking to make mountains out of mole hills. Journalists often misquote or spin the quotes from scientists to support their story agenda. So NEVER take headlines or sound bites at face value, as there is undoubtedly more to the story. That said, reading the BBC or New York Times Science/Health/Environment news is a good first pass to obtain somewhat balanced reporting to keep up to date with the exciting scientific discoveries that are shaping our lives.

Read: Magazine Article

Read this article from Time magazine, "Experimental Drug Helps Treat Osteoporosis."

Now that you have read this article, let's walk through the "science in the media checklist" to properly analyze it from a scientific point of view.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
Throughout the semester, you have been introduced to science. As such, you should now have a better understanding of the scientific method, how science works, and how it is portrayed in the media. In doing so, you are now well on your way to biological literacy, and perhaps unbeknown to you, you have successfully generated hypotheses, collated and analyzed data, as well as drawn conclusions from the information presented. You are now prepared to head out into the world and put your scientific abilities to the test.

The remaining three modules differ in structure from the modules completed so far. Rather than containing content followed by an assessment at the end, Modules 8 and 9 are totally assessment-based. They use assessment questions containing information, data, and media articles as a launchpad to not only test your new scientific knowledge but to learn more about the topics of climate change and pandemics (topics which have been at the forefront of our daily lives over the past couple of years). Finally, Module 10 is a group project that runs over a few weeks where you have the creative freedom to pick a topic of your choice, gather information, and produce a VoiceThread presentation as the assessment outcome.

What is climate change and global warming?

Climate change is a broad term that refers to long-term changes in climate, including average temperature and rainfall change. Global warming is the gradual increase of the Earth's average surface temperature.

During the past 100 years, global average surface temperatures have increased by .9°C (read more about temperature record - if you click on the graph on the wikipedia page, you will see a detailed and referenced description of how the graph was produced). The terms 'global warming' and 'climate change' are often used interchangeably. As a consequence of this and future heating, climate change has been suggested to be one of the greatest social, economic and environmental challenges of our time.

The potential impacts of climate change include temperature increases, sea-level rises, melting of the polar ice-caps, changed weather patterns (droughts and floods), and increased sea temperatures among others. If true, not only will these have an impact on species and ecosystems, but they will have a profound effect on our current way of life.

Click on the image on the right for the full-sized version of "Impacts of Climate Change" for the United States.

What is causing the warming?

What is known for sure is that the incoming energy from the sun in the form of solar radiation passes through the atmosphere and heats the earth's surface. Approximately 50% of the solar energy directed at the earth is directly absorbed at the surface, and the remaining 50% is reflected and radiated back into space in the form of infrared radiation. However, a proportion (22%) of the reflected infrared radiation is trapped by some atmospheric gases (called greenhouse gases), which results in maintaining the Earth's temperature at a level necessary to support life (additional information on the greenhouse effect). The problem we now face is that there is an increasing amount of greenhouse gases (including methane and carbon dioxide) in the atmosphere that trap heat--the so-called greenhouse effect--whereby less heat is escaping and more heat is being trapped within the atmosphere.

Video: Man-made or natural?

Thus, one of the big questions that we are constantly faced with in the media is whether the warming we are experiencing is a natural phenomenon or whether it is due to human influences. There are many Web sites and media outlets out there that portray different points of view on this subject, but if you are interested in more information, Global Issues provides a brief introduction on global warming from both a social and environmental perspective, and Skeptical Science provides a useful synthesis and references to both sides of the global warming debate.

This module explores some of the concerns of the climate change debate. At the conclusion of Lesson 2, you will be required to use your new found scientific logic and problem solving abilities to test some of the potential causes and impacts of increasing global temperatures.

node.title: Lesson 02: Climate change and you
node.body:
Even though climate change and the media coverage surrounding it can appear overwhelming, there are a number of ways you can take direct action to make your home and lifestyle more environmentally friendly and to reduce your personal carbon footprint. A carbon footprint is a measure of the amount of greenhouse gas (or carbon dioxide equivalent) that is produced from our daily activities over the course of a year.

Video: What you can do to help

Take Action: Emissions Calculator

Be pro-active and use the following online emissions calculator to get a rough estimate of your personal or family's greenhouse gas emissions and explore the impact of taking various actions to reduce your emissions. If you do not have access to this type of data from home, try the sample data provided below.

Changing your behavior in small areas can help to have a personal impact on climate change.

Module 8 Assessment Notes

Using the Module 8 assessment in ANGEL, Question 1 explores whether the warming that the Earth is currently exploring is due to natural (increased solar irradiation) or human (increased atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations due to industrialization) causes.  Question 2 focuses on one of the possible impacts of climate change (ocean acidification) and uses real scientific data to explore some of the possible effects of ocean acidification on coral reefs.  Finally, Question 3 uses media articles to assess some of the potential impacts of climate change.

Module 8 Wrap Up

You have just finished Module 8. Not only will you put your new scientific information and skills to good use to explore a topic that will feature as a major part of your lives over the coming years, but hopefully you have a better understanding of how your actions can be directly related to some of the issues raised. node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
Video: Global Swine Flu Cases Close to Pandemic

Flu (also known as influenza) spreads through populations on a yearly basis. The outbreak of H1N1 (otherwise referred to as 'swine') flu has been a major cause of concern globally. Despite the existence of scarier diseases caused by exotic viruses like Ebola, influenza still reigns as the number one infectious killer in modern times. Given the mobility and global nature of the modern world, the influenza virus is no doubt going to have an influence on all of our lives as we move into the future.

In much the same way as with climate change in Module 8, this module is totally assessment based. This module focuses on the recent H1N1 ('swine') flu pandemic as a vehicle to not only broaden your knowledge on the subject of pandemics, but more importantly to put your scientific investigative skills to the test. Module 9 also serves as a "mini-version" of what is expected in your Group Projects (to be introduced in Module 10), and therefore provides you with a test run to cement your skills, to ask questions, and to get feedback before you head off into the Group Project next week.

What is influenza?

Although it is often confused with the common cold, influenza (commonly referred to as the flu) is a much more severe disease than the common cold and is caused by a different type of virus that affects both birds and mammals (additional information on influenza). Influenza is typically transmitted through the air by coughs or sneezes, and the most common symptoms of the disease include chills, fever, sore throat, muscle pains, severe headache, coughing, weakness/fatigue, and general discomfort. In more serious cases, influenza causes pneumonia, which can be fatal, particularly for the young and the elderly. Influenza usually spreads around the world in seasonal epidemics, resulting in the deaths of between 250,000 and 500,000 people every year. However, the death toll can rise into the millions in pandemic years.

What is a pandemic?

The word pandemic originates from the Greek words 'pan' (meaning 'all') and 'demos' (meaning 'people') and is used to describe an epidemic that affects the whole population across every continent. An influenza pandemic occurs when:

  • a new subtype of influenza virus emerges in humans to which most people have not been previously exposed and are, therefore, highly susceptible.
  • the virus causes serious disease in humans.
  • the virus is easily and rapidly spread between humans, infecting large numbers of people worldwide and causing many deaths.

Prior to the recent swine flu outbreak, there have been three major influenza pandemics that have had a significant impact on the world population:

  1. The Spanish flu of 1918 has been the worst influenza pandemic to date, whereby 25% of the world's population was infected with the virus, resulting in an estimated death toll of 50 million people (exceeding the number of people killed during the entire duration of World War 1). 
  2. The Asian flu in 1957 resulted in an estimated death toll of 2 million people.
  3. The Hong Kong flu in 1968 resulted in an estimated death toll of 1 million people. 

According to the World Health Organization, as of February 19, 2010, it is estimated that approximately 16,000 people worldwide have died from the recent H1N1 ('swine') flu virus.  While this may seem like a rather low number compared to the 1918, 1957, and 1968 pandemics, the rapid spread of the recent H1N1 ('swine') flu virus across the world is a cause for alarm and the relatively low death rate to date is also likely to be a function of better health standards, improved communications, and global organizations monitoring and addressing the pandemic in real-time worldwide.

Nevertheless, the threat of the swine flu is not yet over and there is no place for complacency at this stage. The recent H1N1 ('swine') flu is just a modern tangible example of the threat of pandemics (additional information on pandemics) -- the impacts of which go way beyond the direct health issues to having both global social and economic ramifications.

Module 9 Assessment Notes

The H1N1 ('swine') flu virus has had a major impact on countries and people all around the world. Penn State is no different and this module requires your scientific logic and problem-solving abilities to be put to good use as a contracted consultant to address the very real H1N1 ramifications for Penn State. The Penn State administrators have compiled a list of resources and a research question, which are available in the Module 9 assessment in ANGEL. You are required to use the resources provided to address the research question and produce a scientific report.

node.title: Lesson 01: Introduction
node.body:
Project Description

During the course you have developed an enhanced knowledge of the scientific method, a better appreciation for how science works, as well as how science is reported in the media.  Armed with these new skills, you are in a fortunate position to be able to think critically and ask educated and investigative questions.  As part of your assessment for the course, you are required to complete a small project with the end result being a VoiceThread that answers a biological (health or environment) question of your choice.  While the higher level of the project has formal constraints, you are highly encouraged to be as creative as possible in creating your VoiceThread presentations.

The old saying, "you can't believe everything you read" is very true and you are therefore required to do some scientific investigative journalism on a biological topic of your choice, whereby you use supporting evidence to back statements and claims.

Here is a list of the Project Topic Ideas.

Module 10 Structure

Module 10 will be completed over the next four weeks and is broken up into eight lessons to help you pace yourselves as you complete your project. Below is a brief description of each lesson.

  • Lesson 01: this lesson introduces you to the project and Module 10 as a whole.
  • Lesson 02: goes over the project requirements.
  • Lesson 03: describes the project timeline.
  • Lessons 04-07: describes the project work. 
  • Lesson 08: Module and Course Evaluation

Need Help?

We have created a page dedicated with helpful resources for your project. This page is accessible via the Project Help Resources Tab above. There you will find information about the following:

  • whom to contact if you have questions about your research question
  • whom to contact if you have technical issues with VoiceThread
  • links to VoiceThread tutorials and instructions
  • links to sources for images for your project
  • links to resources on using references and project tips

In addition to the Project Help Resources page, we have also created an ANGEL Discussion Forum dedicated to this project. There you can ask questions and see if other students are seeking the same information that you are. The answer to your question might already be there!

node.title: Lesson 02: Project Requirements
node.body:
Project Requirements

The requirements of the project are that you use the scientific method to:

  1. ask an interesting and topical biological question
  2. generate the appropriate Null and Alternative hypothesis
  3. gather the appropriate information from reliable sources to test your hypotheses
  4. use supporting evidence to provide conclusions on your research findings as well as any future studies or recommendations that you think are important or necessary

Additional Project Requirements:

  • The steps of the scientific method need to be followed in the correct and logical order.
  • The VoiceThread needs to be limited to less than five minutes.
  • The text and graphics need to be of sufficient size and quality to be visible on the VoiceThread format.
  • Use at least five 'good quality' reliable references. View the Guide to Referencing.
  • Follow the Project Tips.

VoiceThread Requirements:

  1. Title - should be catchy yet informative. Also a good place to introduce yourself.
  2. Introduction - provide background information and research question.
  3. Hypothesis - Null and Alternative hypotheses stated.
  4. Data Gathered - akin to research methods whereby the data you gathered is summarized and presented in words, tables, graphs, graphics etc.
  5. Conclusion - whether hypotheses were accepted or rejected, why, and what the data is saying.  Include other interesting findings you uncovered during your research or other relating information.
  6. Reference list

Grading Rubric

The TAs will be using the Module 10 Rubric for Students to grade your VoiceThread projects. The TAs will place a √ or X alongside each point and then give you a grade for each of the 8 different sections highlighted in gray. The composite of these 8 subsections will form the final total score.
